title: 107_hr3143
content: The "Freedom to Travel Act of 2001" allows for travel, meals, entertainment, and lodging expenses. The "Freedom to Travel Act of 2001" amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the deduction for meal and entertainment expenses to 80 percent for expenses incurred between the enactment date and December 31, 2002. It also introduces a new subsection for domestic travel expenses, allowing a 50 percent deduction for the first taxable year after December 31, 2001. The "Freedom to Travel Act of 2001" introduces a new subsection for domestic travel expenses, allowing a 50 percent deduction for the first taxable year after December 31, 2001. The deduction is limited to $1,000 for qualified personal travel expenses and $500 for qualified meals, lodging, and entertainment expenses. The "Freedom to Travel Act of 2001" allows a 50 percent deduction for qualified personal travel expenses within the United States, excluding meals, entertainment, and recreation. The farthest destination must be at least 100 miles away. The "Freedom to Travel Act of 2001" allows a 50 percent deduction for qualified personal travel expenses within the United States, excluding meals, entertainment, and recreation. The travel must be at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence, involve an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and be taken on or after the enactment of this subsection. The term does not include travel expenses deductible for a trade or business or income-producing activity. The subsection defines qualified meals, lodging, and entertainment expenses as expenses for food, beverages, lodging at a commercial facility, entertainment, amusement, or recreation in New York City. It includes commercial lodging facilities like hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Special rules apply for substantiation and related persons for deductions. No deduction allowed for expenses provided by related persons or for illegal activities. Double benefits are denied for expenses with other deductions or credits. Domestic travel expenses deduction allowed in computing adjusted gross income. The deduction for domestic travel expenses is allowed in computing adjusted gross income, effective for amounts paid or incurred after the enactment of this Act.
